clauses.head: def assert(value)
clauses.doc: The global entrypoint to writing assertions. `assert` accepts any value or block as an argument, and returns the appropriate assertion object to write assertions with.

AssertionFailure.name: AssertionFailure
AssertionFailure.doc: An AssertionFailure is a container object that is raised when an assertion fails to complete.

Assertion.name: Assertion
Assertion.doc:
An object representing a pending assertion for a static value. Instantiating an `Assertion` object only stores the "left-hand" value. Making actual assertions is done with the instance methods on the object. For example, equality can be asserted with `%Assertion{true}.equals(true)`.
When an assertion succeeds, the method will return normally, but if the assertion fails, the method will raise an `AssertionFailure` object with information about the failure.

clauses.head: def is_truthy
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is truthy (not `false` or `nil`).

clauses.head: def is_falsey
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is falsey (either `false` or `nil`).

clauses.head: def is_true
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is exactly the boolean value `true`.

clauses.head: def is_false
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is exactly the boolean value `false`.

clauses.head: def is_nil
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is `nil` (false is not allowed).

clauses.head: def is_not_nil
clauses.doc: Asserts that the value is not `nil` (false is allowed).

clauses.head: def equals(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is equal to `other` using its `==` method.

clauses.head: def does_not_equal(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is not equal to `other` using its `!=` method.

clauses.head: def less_than(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is less than `other` using its `<` method.

clauses.head: def less_or_equal(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is less than or equal to `other` using its `<=` method.

clauses.head: def greater_or_equal(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is greater than or equal to `other` using its `>=` method.

clauses.head: def greater_than(other)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is greater than `other` using its `>` method.

clauses.head: def between(lower, upper)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is between `lower` and `upper` (inclusively), using only the `<=`operator on the value for comparisons.

clauses.head: def <(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `less_than(other)`.

clauses.head: def <=(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `less_or_equal(other)`.

clauses.head: def ==(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `equals(other)`.

clauses.head: def !=(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `does_not_equal(other)`.

clauses.head: def >=(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `greater_or_equal(other)`.

clauses.head: def >(other)
clauses.doc: Operator alias for `greater_than(other)`.

clauses.head: def is_a(other : Type)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value is an instance of `type`.

clauses.head: def includes(element)
clauses.doc: Assert that the value includes `element`. This requires that the value is Enumerable (implements `#each`)

BlockAssertion.name: BlockAssertion
BlockAssertion.doc:
An object representing a pending assertion for a block of code. Similar to the regular `Assertion`, instantiating a `BlockAssertion` only stores the block of code to be run when making the assertion. Making the actual assertion is done by calling methods on the resulting object.
`BlockAssertion` is most useful for asserting that running a code block has a specific side effect, namely raising errors.

clauses.head: def raises(expected_error)
clauses.doc:
Assert that calling the block raises an error with the given value. If no value is given, the assertion just checks that an error is raised.
The block will be called with whatever arguments have been set with `called_with_arguments`. By default, no arguments will be given.

clauses.head: def succeeds
clauses.doc: Assert that calling the block completes successfully (does not raise an error).

clauses.head: def returns(expected_result)
clauses.doc: Assert that calling the block returns the given value.

clauses.head: def called_with_arguments(*args)
clauses.doc: Set the arguments to be used when calling the block for an assertion.

clauses.head: def map(&block)
clauses.doc: Call `block` for each element of `self` and collect the result for each call into a new List. If `each` does not yield any elements, the result will be an empty List.

clauses.head: def join(delimiter : String)
clauses.doc: Creates a new string from the result of calling `to_s` on every element of `self`, inserting `delimiter` between each element.

clauses.head: def size
clauses.doc: Returns the size of the enumerable, as determined by the number of elements yielded by `each`.

clauses.head: def all?(&block)
clauses.doc: Return true if all elements in the enumerable cause `block` to return a truthy value.

clauses.head: def any?(&block)
clauses.doc: Return true if at least one element in the enumerable evaluates to a truthy value for the given block.

clauses.head: def find(&block)
clauses.doc: Iterate the enumerable, passing each element to `block`. Return the first element for which the block returns a truthy value.

clauses.head: def select(&block)
clauses.doc: Iterate the enumerable, passing each element to `block`. Return all elements for which the block returns a truthy value.

clauses.head: def min
clauses.doc: Returns the element with the lowest value as determined by <.

clauses.head: def max
clauses.doc: Returns the element with the highest value as determined by >.

clauses.head: def sort
clauses.doc: Returns a sorted list of all elements.

clauses.head: def to_list
clauses.doc: Returns a list containing all elements.

clauses.head: def reduce(&block)
clauses.doc:
For every element in the enumerable, call block with the result of the previous call and the current element as arguments. Returns a single value.
If an initial value is given, it will be used as the accumulator argument for the block call with the first element. If an initial value is not given, the first element will not be passed to the block and will be be used as the accumulator for the block call with the second element.

Spec.name: Spec
Spec.doc:
A simple library for writing specs around Myst code. Specs are written using `it`, providing either a name, a code block to test, or both. Multiple `it`s can be organized under a `describe` block for better visual clarity.
The Spec library operates primarily through `assert`. Each spec can make multiple calls to `assert`, with an argument that is expected to be truthy. If the given argument is not truthy, the spec is considered failed, and the suite will not pass.
By default, a passing assertion will output a green `.` to the terminal, while a failing assertion will output a red `F`. For now, execution will immediately halt on the first assertion failure, and the program will exit with a non-zero status code.

AssertionFailure.name: AssertionFailure
AssertionFailure.doc: An AssertionFailure is a container object that is raised when an assertion made within an `it` block fails. The failure contains the Spec object that failed, the value that was expected, and the value that was received.

File.name: File
File.doc:
A high-level representation of a File on the system. Creating a new File object will immediately open it.
The Myst interpreter does not currently ensure that files are automatically closed when the object is destroyed. As such, it is important to remember to close a File object when you are done using it, or use the static versions of the File methods to avoid creating new File objects in the first place.

clauses.head: def path
clauses.doc: Returns the path specified when opening this File. The path will not be expanded or modified from what was given to the initializer for this File object.

clauses.head: def mode
clauses.doc: Returns the mode that this File was opened with; one of `"r"`, `"w"`, `"a"`, or `"b"`.

clauses.head: def close
clauses.doc: Flushes and closes this File object's file handle, removing it from the open file pool.

clauses.head: def size
clauses.doc: Returns the size, in bytes, of this File.

clauses.head: defstatic open(path : String, mode : String)
clauses.doc:
Creates a new File object for the file specified by `path` and opens it using the given opening mode. The mode can be any of the standard opening modes: `r`, `w`, `a`, or `b`.
If a file is being created, its initial permissions are set using the default creation permissions for the system.
This should be the preferred method for creating new File objects, rather than directly instantiating new File objects.

clauses.head: defstatic open(path : String)
clauses.doc: Opens the file specified by `path` in reading mode (`"r"`).

clauses.head: defstatic basename(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns the last path component of `path`, determined by splitting `path` based on the system's default path separator. This method acts like the inverse of `dirname`.

clauses.head: defstatic chmod(path : String, mode : Integer)
clauses.doc:
Changes the permissions of the file specified by `path` to those represented by `mode`.
Since Myst does not currently support octal literals (as mode strings are generally written), the easiest way to specify the mode is to use `String#to_i` with a `base` of 8.
For example: `File.chmod(file, "644".to_i(8))`.

clauses.head: defstatic delete(path : String)
clauses.doc:
Attempts to delete the file specified by `path` from the file system.
This method may raise a RuntimeError if the file does not exist.

clauses.head: defstatic directory?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists and is a directory.

clauses.head: defstatic dirname(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns a new String of `path` with last path component removed. This method acts like the inverse of `basename`.

clauses.head: defstatic each_line(file_name : String, &block)
clauses.doc:
Opens the file specified by `file_name` and iterates the content line-by-line. Each line is passed to `block`.
This method is useful for parsing large files, since the entire file does not have to be loaded into memory at one time.

clauses.head: defstatic empty?(path : String)
clauses.doc:
Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists but has no content.
This method may raise a RuntimeError if the file does not exist.

clauses.head: defstatic executable?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists and is executable by the real user of the process calling this method.

clauses.head: defstatic exists?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists on the filesystem.

clauses.head: defstatic expand_path(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns a new String reprenting the expansion of `path` to an absolute path. Relative paths are referenced from the current working directory of the process calling this method.

clauses.head: defstatic extname(path : String)
clauses.doc:
Returns the extension of the file specified by `path`. The extension is considered the string after the last dot (`.`) in the `path`.
If the file has no extension, this method returns a new, empty String.

clauses.head: defstatic file?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists and is a file.

clauses.head: defstatic join(*parts)
clauses.doc: Returns a new String containing all of the elements of `parts` joined together using the system's default path separator.

clauses.head: defstatic lines(file_name : String)
clauses.doc:
Opens the file specified by `file_name` and returns a new List containing each line of the file as elements.
For large files (and almost always) `File.each_line` should be preferred, as it will avoid reading the entire file into memory at one time.

clauses.head: defstatic link(old_path : String, new_path : String)
clauses.doc: Creates a new (hard) link at `new_path` to the existing file at `old_path`.

clauses.head: defstatic read(path : String)
clauses.doc: Opens the file specified by `path` and returns a single string containing the entire content of the file.

clauses.head: defstatic readable?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists and is readable by the real user of the process calling this method.

clauses.head: defstatic real_path(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns the real path of `path` by following symlinks. The file specified by the resulting path is not guaranteed to exist (e.g., if the symlink is broken).

clauses.head: defstatic rename(old_name : String, new_name : String)
clauses.doc:
Moves the file specified by `old_name` to `new_name`.
This method may raise a RuntimeError if the file specified by `new_name` already exists or can not be created.

clauses.head: defstatic size(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns the size of the file specified by `path` represented in bytes.

clauses.head: defstatic symlink(old_path : String, new_path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns the last path component of `path`, determined by splitting `path` based on the system's default path separator.

clauses.head: defstatic symlink?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` is a symbolic link.

clauses.head: defstatic touch(path : String)
clauses.doc:
Attempts to set the access and modification times of the file specified by `path` to the current time.
If the file does not exist, it will be created.

clauses.head: defstatic writable?(path : String)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if the file specified by `path` exists and is writable by the real user of the process calling this method.

clauses.head: defstatic write(path : String, content : String)
clauses.doc:
Writes the bytes of `content` to the file specified by `path`. `content` is assumed to already by a String value; no conversions will be performed.
If the file already exists, it will be overwritten. Otherwise, a new file will be created.

clauses.head: def initialize(path : String, mode : String)
clauses.doc:
Creates a new File object for the file specified by `path` and opens it using the given opening mode. The mode can be any of the standard opening modes: `r`, `w`, `a`, or `b`.
If a file is being created, its initial permissions are set using the default creation permissions for the system.

clauses.head: def times(&block)
clauses.doc: Call block as many times as the value of this integer.

clauses.head: def print(value)
clauses.doc: Writes the given value through this IO, in order. The value will be converted to a string by calling `to_s` on it, then written to the IO using `write`.

clauses.head: def puts
clauses.doc:
Writes the given values through this IO, in order. Each value will be converted to a string by calling `to_s` on it, then written to the IO using `write`.
Unlike `print`, each value will also be succeeded by a newline character. If no arguments are given, a single newline character will be written to the IO.

clauses.head: def gets
clauses.doc:
Reads from the IO until a newline character is found. Returns a String containing all of the characters read from the IO, excluding the newline character.
If a `read` call returns an empty String before a newline character is found, the characters up until that point will be returned.

clauses.head: def to_s
clauses.doc:
Creates a string representation of this List by calling `join` with the delimiter set as `,`. The result will be wrapped in square brackets.
For example: `[1,2,3].to_s` will yield `[1,2,3]`.

clauses.head: def empty?
clauses.doc: Return `true` if the List contains 0 elements. Return `false` otherwise.

clauses.head: def empty?
clauses.doc: Return `true` if the Map contains 0 entries. Return `false` otherwise.

clauses.head: def empty?
clauses.doc: Return `true` if the String contains 0 characters. Return `false` otherwise.

clauses.head: def validate(year, month, day, hour, minute, second, nanosecond)
def initialize(year, month, day, hour, minute)
def initialize(year, month, day, hour, minute, second)
def initialize(year, month, day, hour, minute, second, nanosecond)

Util.name: Util
Util.doc: A module containing utility functions and constants for performing calculations with times. This module is primarily used by the `Time` type to properly translate between componentized time objects and seconds or nanoseconds.

DAYS_MONTH.name: DAYS_MONTH
DAYS_MONTH.doc: An array representing the number of days in each month of a normal year, with January being month `0`.

DAYS_MONTH_LEAP.name: DAYS_MONTH_LEAP
DAYS_MONTH_LEAP.doc: Similar to `DAYS_MONTH`, but for the months of a leap year.

clauses.head: def convert_to_seconds(year, month, day, hour, minute, second)

Boolean.name: Boolean
Boolean.doc: A Boolean is an object representing either `true` or `false` values. The only way to create new Boolean objects is to use the boolean literals `true` and `false`.

clauses.head: def to_s
clauses.doc: Returns either `"true"` or `"false"` depending on this Boolean's value.

clauses.head: def ==(other)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if `other` has the same value as this Boolean (i.e., both are `true` or both are `false`). If `other` is _not_ a Boolean, this method will return `false`.

clauses.head: def !=(other)
clauses.doc: Returns `true` if `other` has any value other than the value of this Boolean. Only returns `false` if `other` is a Boolean and has the same value as this Boolean.
